questions.question_text:
Refer to the exhibit. In this BGP setup, 10.1.1.0/24 is advertised by AS 400 to its peers. Border routers in AS 100 reset the next-hop router to themselves. R2, R3, and R4 are route reflector clients of R1 and R5 is a non-client iBGP peer of R1. What is the BGP next hop on R5 for the address 10.1.1.0/24?
//IMG//

discussion.content:
Per the best path rule, the path with the highest Weight is preferred.
Per the diagram the RR sets Metric (I assume it points to Weight) as 20, so only the path with next-hop R2 is selected as the best.
R2 is also the next-hop for R5 to reach the destination.

The metric here actually points to the attribute Weight, which is compared first before MED.
R4 is correct.
As per BGP best path calculation it should be R2 as R2 received the route with lowest MED value.

comments.content:
Nope: R4, as metric comes first:
 R2 has 20, R3/R4 have 10. Now MED lets R4 be prefered over R3.

choices.D: The mapping can be done statically at the Layer 3 multicast routers.
choices.E: The Layer 2 switches can transform the IGMPv2 join to an IGMPv3lite join.
choices.A: The Layer 2 switches can send a request to a DNS server.
choices.B: The Layer 3 multicast routers can send a request to a DNS server.
choices.F: The Layer 3 multicast routers can transform the IGMPv2 join to an IGMPv3lite join.
choices.C: The mapping can be done statically at the Layer 2 switches.

questions.question_text: A company wants to use SSM as the multicast routing protocol inside its network. Some of its multicast applications do not support IGMPv3. In which two ways can the mapping be done when these applications send IGMPv2 join messages? (Choose two.)
You have been tasked to create a Layer 2 network design that uses vPC to provide resiliency and avoid loops. vPC removes Layer 2 loops while providing redundancy through which mechanism?

discussion.content: D is incorrect. C is correct. ba just for loop prevention

choices.C: when your service provider requires the DSCP bits be set
choices.B: when you are marking packets with the TOS bits
choices.D: when the QoS policy cannot be based on DSCP ToS bits
choices.A: when you are marking packets with the DSCP bits

questions.question_text: You are designing the QoS features for a large enterprise network that includes DMVPN. When would you need to configure QoS preclassify?

choices.C: Network address translation functions interfere with tunnel header preservation.
choices.B: GDOI is less secure than traditional IPsec.
choices.D: The use of public addresses is not supported with GDOI.
choices.A: Enterprise host IP addresses are typically not routable.

questions.question_text: Which restriction prevents a designer from using a GDOI-based VPN to secure traffic that traverses the Internet?

discussion.content:
C is correct.
https://networklessons.com/cisco/ccie-routing-switching-written/group-encrypted-transport-vpn-getvpn
"One disadvantage, however, is that you can’t use address preservation on the Internet since private IP addresses are unroutable. It’s incompatible with NAT since NAT makes changes to the outer IP header."
